item.title: A fistful of ducats
item.description: Some notes on utility and insurance. The below is apropos of ET Jaynes’ Probability Theory, Chapter 13. It’s a useful and interesting book, but Jaynes was apparently no great believer in graphical illustrations. Utility functions Daniel Bernoulli, one of the many Bernoullis, conceived a utility function \(u(x) \propto log(x)\) in contrast to the linear \(u(x) \propto x\), usual at the time. Naturally \(x\) denotes money: Gambling was the principal object of probability arguments in the mid-1700s.
